metadata.titleEn: HiWATER: Dataset of hydrometeorological observation network (an automatic weather station of Sidaoqiao populus forest station, 2014)
metadata.description:
This data set contains meteorological element observation data of Euphrates poplar forest station downstream of heihe hydrometeorological observation network from January 1, 2014 to December 31, 2014.The station is located in Inner Mongolia ejin banner dalaihubu town four road bridge, under the surface is hu Yang Lin and tamarix.The longitude and latitude of the observation point are 101.1239e, 41.9932n and 876m above sea level.The air temperature and relative humidity sensors are located at 28m, facing due north.The wind speed sensor is located at 28m, facing due north.Two four-component radiometers were installed at 6m and 24m respectively, facing due south;Two infrared thermometers are installed at 24m, facing due south and the probe facing vertically downward.Two photosynthetically active radiators were installed at a position of 24m, facing due south, with one probe vertically upward and one probe vertically downward.The soil temperature probe is buried at 0cm on the surface and 2cm and 4cm underground, 2m to the south of the meteorological tower.The soil moisture sensor (installed on March 15, 2014) was buried 2cm and 4cm underground, located 2m to the south of the meteorological tower.The soil heat flow plates (3 pieces) are buried in the ground 6cm underground, 2m to the south of the meteorological tower.
Observation projects are: air temperature and humidity (Ta_28m, RH_28m) (unit: c, percentage), wind speed (WS_28m) (unit: m/s), the radiation of 24 m four component (DR_1 UR_1 DLR_Cor_1 ULR_Cor_1 Rn_1) (unit: watts per square meter), the radiation of 6 m four component (DR_2 UR_2 DLR_Cor_2 ULR_Cor_2 Rn_2) (unit: watts per square meter), the surface radiation temperature (IRT_1, IRT_2) (unit:Degrees Celsius), soil heat flux (Gs_1, Gs_2, Gs_3) (unit: watts per square meter), soil temperature (Ts_0cm Ts_2cm Ts_4cm) (unit: c), soil moisture (Ms_2cm, Ms_4cm) (unit: volumetric water content, percentage), up and down photosynthetic active radiation (PAR_up, PAR_down) (unit: second micromoles/m2).
Processing and quality control of observed data :(1) ensure 144 pieces of data every day (every 10min), and mark by -6999 in case of data missing;(2) excluding the time with duplicate records;(3) data that obviously exceeds the physical significance or the range of the instrument is deleted;(4) the part marked with red letter in the data is the data in question;(5) date and time have the same format, and date and time are in the same column.For example, the time is: September 10, 2014, 10:30;(6) the naming rule is: AWS+ site name.
For information of hydrometeorological network or station, please refer to Li et al.(2013), and for observation data processing, please refer to Liu et al.(2011).

background: The two-source energy balance (TSEB) model was successfully applied to estimate evaporation (E), transpiration (T), and evapotranspiration (ET) for land covered with vegetation, which has significantly important applications for the terrestrial water cycle and water resource management. One-source evapotranspiration estimation models combine the soil–vegetation components into a single source. However, in real landscape conditions, the surface is heterogeneous and contains a mixture of soil and vegetation having different temperatures and resistance to energy exchange. Therefore, one-source models explicitly cannot estimate the surface evapotranspiration accurately because the effect of.

Shuttleworth and Wallace proposed a typical two-source evapotranspiration estimation model in which the energy partition is assumed to occur in both “the above canopy” and “the under soil” cases. Water vapor and heat meet over the reference height in the interior of the canopy. Moreover, the mixed water vapor and heat can only exit through the top of the canopy; the total heat flux is in addition to the fluxes coming from every surface layer. However, the model is complex, having over five resistances that cannot be accurately calculated. In addition, the model includes required parameters and observations that cannot be readily obtained from operational satellite- and ground-based data; therefore, the range of applications of the model is limited.

The TSEB model has undergone several revisions, improving the estimation of soil and canopy net radiation, the aerodynamic resistance of the soil surface, the fractional vegetation coverage observed at the radiometer view angle, the distribution of regional-scale near-surface air temperature, and soil and canopy component temperatures. Because the TSEB model only requires the surface energy balance model with a single measurement of land surface temperature, the original model and subsequent refinements have been widely used to estimate E and T under a wide variety of vegetation types, vegetation coverage, climates, and spatial scales. However, most studies have only evaluated the total fluxes or ET (soil plus canopy) in comparison with measurements using the Bowen ratio–energy balance system, the eddy covariance (EC) system, or the large aperture scintillometer.

Accurately estimating surface fluxes in a strongly advective irrigated agricultural area is a particularly challenging task and is even more difficult when the EC flux measurements of H and LE have an incomplete energy balance closure with respect to the available energy Rn−G0. The previous sensitivity studies found that the TSEB model performance is mainly affected by the uncertainty in surface–air temperature difference. Sometimes, this difference is dominant due to the errors in determining the surface soil and vegetation component temperatures from the surface composite radiometric temperature. In this letter, it is shown that there is an overestimation of the component temperatures compared with the observed composite radiometric. This often leads to the most crucial effect on the TSEB model performance. In addition, another factor is the strong advective environment in this region.
research objective: In this letter, the ground-measured soil and canopy component temperatures were used to estimate E, T, and ET, which were better validated with observed ratios of E (E/ET%) and T (T/ET%) using the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotopes, and the ET measurements using an eddy covariance (EC) system.

The objective of this letter is to estimate E, T, and ET using the soil and canopy component temperatures observed via a high-resolution thermal camera as inputs to a series TSEB model and to subsequently better validate E, T, and ET using a combination of the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotope technique and EC measurements.
challenges: However, the current composite temperature separation approaches are limited in their effectiveness in arid regions. Moreover, E and T are difficult to measure on the ground.

Errors in the derived component temperature were primarily caused by image classification errors; these classification errors varied with vegetation abundance. The higher uncertainty of H estimation is not only caused by the uncertainty of the TSEB model but also due to the increased uncertainty of the EC system, which is 18% when the mean H is small in the irrigated farmland. Due to image pixel classification errors, soil pixels were counted as vegetation pixels, which produced an overestimation of the canopy temperature under the developing vegetation abundance. Alternatively, ignoring atmospheric upwelling radiation and transmittance could have produced the uncertainties in the estimated temperatures. In addition, the estimated uncertainty of the incoming short- and long-wave radiation transmittances through the canopy may be another source of Rn estimation errors.
methods: In this letter, the field observations were obtained from the Daman superstation installed in the central oasis, which is a 40-m boundary layer tower located at 100.3722° E, 38.8555° N and at an elevation of 1556 m. The meteorological parameters were measured every 10 min and included air temperature, wind speed, humidity at 5 m over the ground, four-component radiations (measured at 12 m above the ground using a four-component radiometer), and turbulent fluxes (measured at 4.5 m above the ground using an EC system with a sampling frequency of 10 Hz). The soil heat fluxes were measured using three heat plates located 6 cm under the ground. A Fluke Ti55 thermal infrared camera was manually operated on a 25-m-high platform on a boundary layer tower to measure the thermal radiation of the cropland approximately every 120 min; the observations were collected as thermal images from approximately 07:00 to 19:00 China Standard Time (CST) during the daytime. The ground-based measurement data were applied to partition ET into E and T applying the Craig–Gordon model.

To evaluate the TSEB model accurately, the soil heat flux was using the ground measurement. In addition, the soil and canopy sensible heat fluxes were estimated using the series TSEB model, and their latent heat fluxes were calculated while solving the energy balance equations (1) and (2), respectively. The soil and canopy component temperatures were calculated using the images obtained with the thermal camera. To calculate the component temperatures, the visible and NIR images were classified into soil and canopy pixels using the maximum-likelihood method. Next, the soil and canopy directional brightness temperatures were exacted from the thermal images. Finally, the thermal infrared temperatures were converted to the radiation temperatures using the incoming long-wave radiation from the sky and the soil and canopy emissivities. Next, the simulated radiometric temperatures were validated against the surface radiometric temperatures, which were calculated according to the incoming long-wave radiation observed by the four-component radiometer.
dataset: The experimental area is an artificial oasis that is covered with maize, vegetables, and orchards. Data of day of year (DOY) 170, 173, 176, 192, 195, 231, 252, and 256 were used to determine ET and the ratios of E (E/ET%) and T (T/ET%) to ET during the Multi-Scale Observation Experiment on Evapotranspiration over heterogeneous land surfaces, which was part of the Heihe Water Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER-MUSOEXE).
findings: Our results indicated that even under the strongly advective conditions, the TSEB model produced reliable estimates of the E/ET% and T/ET% ratios and of ET. The mean bias and root-mean-square error (RMSE) of E/ET% were 1% and 2%, respectively, and the mean bias and RMSE of T/ET% were −1% and 2%, respectively. In addition, the model exhibited relatively reliable estimates in the latent heat flux, with mean bias and RMSE values of 31 and 61 W·m−2, respectively, compared with the measurements from the EC system. These results demonstrated that a robust soil and vegetation component temperature calculation was crucial for estimating E, T, and ET. Moreover, the separate validation of E/ET% and T/ET% provides a good prospect for TSEB model improvements.

Our results demonstrated that the TSEB model using soil and canopy component radiometric temperatures, which were obtained from a high-precision thermal infrared camera, can be applied in a strongly advection-irrigated agricultural area. Notably, the results illustrated that the latent fluxes of the soil and vegetation components were successfully separated with reasonable accuracy, as assessed using ground-based measurements. The estimated E/ET% and E/ET% values agreed well with the values observed using the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotopes technique during the early, middle, and late growing seasons. In addition, the TSEB model produced reliable estimations of Rn, H, and LE; the mean biases of Rn, H, and LE were −18, 5, and 31 W ·m−2, respectively, and the RMSEs of Rn, H, and LE were 29, 19, and 61 W · m−2, respectively. This finding suggests that given accurate soil and vegetation component temperatures, E and T can be accurately separated from ET using the TSEB model.

background: Arid and semiarid regions represent approximately 30 % of the global terrestrial surface area (Dregne, 1991; Scanlon et al., 2006), and dryland expansion occurs under climate change, especially in developing countries (Huang et al., 2016). An oasis is a unique ecological landscape in arid and semi-arid areas that is not only the core of regions’ ecological environment but also the foundation of their economic development, especially in western China, which has been an important part of the “Silk Road” since ancient times. Oases comprising less than 10 % of the total area of arid regions support more than 90 % of the population in these regions of China (Chu et al., 2005; Li et al., 2016; Zhou et al., 2022). The oasis–desert system plays a crucial role in maintaining a stable ecological environment and agricultural productivity (Zhang and Zhao, 2015). Extensive studies have investigated energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas based on field and remote-sensing observations (Taha et al., 1991; Potchter et al., 2008; Xue et al., 2019; Wang et al., 2019; Zhou et al., 2022) and numerical simulations (Chu et al., 2005; Meng et al., 2009; Georgescu et al., 2011; Liu et al., 2020). In addition, oasis–desert areas located in semiarid regions have been found to be carbon sinks by previous researchers (Tagesson et al., 2016; Wang et al., 2019); thus, they can significantly affect the carbon balance of arid regions and play an increasingly important role within the global carbon cycle.
research objective: Therefore, it is critical to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems in order to achieve the goal of sustainable oasis development. Understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is important to achieve the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in the oasis–desert area and support the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis. A quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas is crucial to recognize the oasis–desert interactions and is significant to protect the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases; moreover, long-term observations are indispensable.
challenges: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas are facing the crisis of ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, the degradation of natural vegetation, the intensification of land desertification, and the frequent occurrence of dust storms, especially in many inland river basins westward along the Silk Road, such as the Tarim River basin (Zhao et al., 2013), the Aral Sea basin (Stanev et al., 2004; Crétaux et al., 2009), and the Lake Urmia basin (Stone, 2015).
methods: In this study, we present a suite of observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems that consist of long-term energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes as well as auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters from 2012 to 2021. Half-hourly turbulent flux data were acquired by an eddy covariance system and scintillometer. The hydrometeorological data (including radiation, soil heat flux, and soil temperature profiles; gradients of air temperature and humidity and of wind speed and direction; and air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles) were observed from automatic weather stations with a 10 min average period as well as the groundwater table data. Moreover, vegetation and soil parameters were also supplemented in the datasets. The data processing and quality control procedure can be divided into data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing.
dataset: The study area comprises the middle and lower reaches of the HRB, located in the arid regions of western China, that receive water from the typical cryosphere of the upper reaches. A total of 11 land surface flux and meteorological stations have been established in these regions since 2012 – 2 superstations and 9 ordinary stations. The dataset of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations in oasis–desert areas reported in this study (including energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes; hydrometeorological data; and vegetation and soil parameters) is freely available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a method used to ensure data quality and control during data collection in hydrometeorological observational studies?
Example.Answer: In hydrometeorological observational studies, data quality and control are ensured by several methods, such as ensuring that there are 144 data entries per day (one every 10 minutes) and marking any missing data with a specific value like -6999. Duplicate records are removed, data exceeding physical or instrument limits are deleted, and any questionable data are marked in red. Additionally, date and time are formatted consistently, and naming conventions are standardized, as seen in the dataset of the Heihe River Basin.

Example.Question: What is an example of a dataset that combines ground-based measurements with model estimations to study evapotranspiration in heterogeneous land surfaces?
Example.Answer: A dataset combining ground-based measurements with model estimations to study evapotranspiration in heterogeneous land surfaces can be found in the study involving the Multi-Scale Observation Experiment on Evapotranspiration over heterogeneous land surfaces. This dataset is part of the Heihe Water Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER-MUSOEXE) and includes data used to determine evapotranspiration and its components using the TSEB model and validated with eddy covariance measurements.

Example.Question: Provide an example of how long-term observational datasets are used to study energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems.
Example.Answer: An example of long-term observational datasets used to study energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems can be found in the data collected from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems in the middle and lower reaches of the Heihe River Basin (HRB). These datasets, collected from 2012 to 2021, include turbulent flux data, hydrometeorological data, and vegetation and soil parameters, and are available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.

Definition.Question: What is the significance of the 'eddy covariance system' in data collection for hydrometeorological research?
Definition.Answer: The eddy covariance system is crucial for measuring turbulent fluxes, such as energy, water vapor, carbon, and methane fluxes, which are essential for understanding energy and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems.

Definition.Question: How is the term 'two-source energy balance (TSEB) model' defined in the context of evapotranspiration estimation?
Definition.Answer: The two-source energy balance (TSEB) model is used to estimate evaporation, transpiration, and evapotranspiration by considering separate soil and canopy components, which is important for accurately modeling energy exchanges in heterogeneous landscapes.

Comparison.Question: In what ways do the challenges of measuring evapotranspiration in heterogeneous landscapes differ when using a one-source model versus a two-source model like the TSEB?
Comparison.Answer: One-source models, which combine soil and vegetation components into a single source, often struggle with accuracy in heterogeneous landscapes where different surfaces exhibit varying temperatures and resistances. This results in less precise evapotranspiration estimates. Two-source models like the TSEB separate these components, allowing for more detailed representation of energy partitioning and surface interactions, thus providing more accurate estimates. However, they require more complex inputs and calibration, such as component temperatures, making them more challenging to implement but potentially more effective in diverse landscape conditions.

Interpretation.Question: How might the integration of ground-based measurements and satellite data improve the accuracy of energy balance models in oasis-desert ecosystems?
Interpretation.Answer: The integration of ground-based measurements, such as those from a high-resolution thermal camera and an eddy covariance system, with satellite data can enhance the accuracy of energy balance models by providing comprehensive datasets that capture both soil and canopy component temperatures. This allows for better validation of model estimates against observed ratios of evaporation and transpiration, and can help address issues related to the heterogeneity of the landscape and the strong advective conditions in arid regions.

Interpretation.Question: What challenges might arise in using composite temperature separation approaches in arid regions, and how can these be addressed through data collection methods?
Interpretation.Answer: Challenges in using composite temperature separation approaches in arid regions include errors in image classification that affect the estimation of soil and canopy temperatures, especially with varying vegetation abundance. These challenges can be addressed by employing accurate classification methods, such as the maximum-likelihood method, and by using high-precision thermal infrared cameras to obtain reliable radiometric temperatures. Additionally, accounting for atmospheric variables like upwelling radiation and transmittance can reduce uncertainties in temperature estimations.

Interpretation.Question: What data collection strategies can be employed to understand the interactions between energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis-desert systems?
Interpretation.Answer: To understand the interactions between energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis-desert systems, data collection strategies should include long-term observational datasets from both artificial and natural systems. This involves using an eddy covariance system and scintillometer to measure turbulent fluxes, automatic weather stations for hydrometeorological data, and supplementary vegetation and soil parameters. Such comprehensive datasets allow for a quantitative understanding of these interactions and support the ecological stability and sustainable development of oases.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the underlying reasons for the observed discrepancies in energy balance closure when using eddy covariance systems in irrigated agricultural areas?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Discrepancies in energy balance closure with eddy covariance systems are primarily due to the strong advective conditions in irrigated agricultural areas. These conditions cause errors in estimating surface-air temperature differences, which are crucial for accurate flux measurements. The complex nature of soil and canopy interactions under advective conditions, coupled with uncertainties in component temperature determination, further complicates achieving energy balance closure.

Causal Consequence.Question: How does the inclusion of soil and vegetation component temperatures influence the accuracy of evapotranspiration estimates using the TSEB model?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Including soil and vegetation component temperatures enhances the accuracy of evapotranspiration estimates when using the TSEB model. By utilizing ground-measured soil and canopy component temperatures, the TSEB model can better partition evaporation (E) and transpiration (T). This approach helps in producing reliable estimates of E/ET% and T/ET% ratios, as well as overall ET, under various vegetation types and climatic conditions, particularly in complex heterogeneous landscapes.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the consequences of using a thermal infrared camera for measuring soil and canopy component temperatures in terms of data accuracy for energy flux estimations?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Utilizing a thermal infrared camera for measuring soil and canopy component temperatures can significantly enhance the accuracy of data used in energy flux estimations. The high precision of thermal infrared cameras allows for accurate separation of soil and canopy temperatures, which is crucial for calculating latent and sensible heat fluxes accurately. This method provides robust temperature data that improve the performance of models like TSEB, leading to more reliable estimates of energy fluxes and evapotranspiration in diverse environmental settings.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the primary objective of collecting hydrometeorological data in oasis–desert systems using an array of automated weather stations and land surface flux stations?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objective is to understand the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems, which is crucial for achieving the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality, supporting ecological security, and ensuring sustainable development of oases.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to use a series TSEB model and high-resolution thermal camera for estimating evaporation, transpiration, and evapotranspiration in a strongly advective irrigated agricultural area?
Goal Orientation.Answer: It is important because the TSEB model, combined with soil and canopy component temperatures from a high-resolution thermal camera, allows for accurate separation of latent fluxes from soil and vegetation components, which is critical for estimating evaporation, transpiration, and evapotranspiration in such challenging environments.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the long-term goals of maintaining a balance between oasis and desert systems through the collection of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange data?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The long-term goals include protecting ecological stability, supporting socioeconomic development, and recognizing oasis–desert interactions, which are significant for the sustainable development of oases and for addressing ecological challenges in arid and semiarid regions.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are involved in ensuring the quality control of meteorological data collected from an automatic weather station in an arid region?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The quality control of meteorological data involves ensuring that there are 144 data points each day, marking missing data with a specific code (-6999), removing duplicate records, deleting data that are outside physical limits or instrument ranges, and marking questionable data in red. Additionally, the date and time formats are standardized, and naming rules are applied to the datasets.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How is the separation of evapotranspiration into soil and canopy components achieved using remote sensing and field data?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The separation of evapotranspiration into soil and canopy components is achieved by using a two-source energy balance model (TSEB) that utilizes ground-measured soil and canopy component temperatures. High-resolution thermal imagery is used to extract soil and canopy temperatures, which are then processed through classification methods to distinguish between soil and canopy pixels. These temperatures are then used in combination with energy balance equations to estimate the latent heat fluxes of soil and canopy separately.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements have enabled the detailed measurement of soil and canopy component temperatures in heterogeneous landscapes?
Enablement.Answer: The use of high-resolution thermal cameras and the application of the two-source energy balance (TSEB) model have enabled the detailed measurement of soil and canopy component temperatures. These advancements allow for more accurate estimation of evaporation, transpiration, and evapotranspiration by separating soil and vegetation component temperatures from composite radiometric temperatures.

Enablement.Question: What methods enable the separation and accurate estimation of latent heat fluxes of soil and vegetation components in a strongly advective irrigated agricultural area?
Enablement.Answer: The separation and accurate estimation of latent heat fluxes of soil and vegetation components are enabled by the TSEB model, which utilizes soil and canopy component radiometric temperatures obtained from high-precision thermal infrared cameras. This model facilitates reliable estimations of energy partitioning in complex environments such as strongly advective irrigated agricultural areas.

Expectation.Question: What reasons could explain the limited application range of certain evapotranspiration models in heterogeneous landscapes?
Expectation.Answer: The limited application range of certain evapotranspiration models in heterogeneous landscapes can be attributed to the complexity of capturing the mixed soil and vegetation characteristics, as well as the difficulty in obtaining necessary model parameters and observations from operational satellite- and ground-based data. Additionally, these models often require detailed component temperature measurements that are not readily available.

Expectation.Question: Why is there a need for long-term observational datasets in understanding energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis-desert ecosystems?
Expectation.Answer: Long-term observational datasets are crucial for understanding the dynamic interactions and balance between energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis-desert ecosystems. Such datasets provide comprehensive insights into the temporal variability and trends necessary for ecological stability, sustainable development, and achieving carbon neutrality goals, especially in the face of climate change and ecological degradation.

Judgmental.Question: In what ways can long-term observational datasets contribute to a better understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Judgmental.Answer: Long-term observational datasets provide critical insights into the dynamics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems by capturing temporal variations and trends over extended periods. These datasets allow researchers to study the interactions between oasis and desert systems, assess the impact of climate change, and evaluate the ecological stability and carbon balance within these regions. They also support the development of models and strategies for sustainable oasis development and ecological security, offering a quantitative basis for recognizing oasis–desert interactions.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore and describe the methods used for data collection in hydrometeorological networks, particularly focusing on how sensor placements and orientations affect data quality and accuracy.
Request/Directive.Answer: In hydrometeorological networks, such as those monitoring the Heihe River Basin, sensors are strategically placed to capture accurate atmospheric and soil data. For instance, air temperature and relative humidity sensors are positioned at a height of 28 meters, facing north, to minimize interference from surrounding vegetation and structures. Wind speed sensors are also placed at the same height and orientation. Radiation instruments are set at varying heights (6m and 24m) and orientations to capture comprehensive solar and thermal data. Soil temperature and moisture sensors are embedded at different depths and distances from the meteorological tower to ensure accurate ground-level readings. Such careful sensor positioning and orientation are crucial for minimizing data inaccuracies due to environmental obstructions and ensuring the integrity of the dataset for further analysis and application.
